1 - Post Traumatic Growth For Social Entrepreneurs 
Insights from the 2020 Beirut Port Explosion.
Background:
The decade of the 2020’s is marked by a series of compounding crises, the coronavirus pandemic, intensifying climactic events due to the climate crisis, and, relatedly, the increase in socio-political disorder. It is in this context this research has been conducted with a group of education oriented social entrepreneurs working in Lebanon. During our qualitative and quantitative study our participants experienced a combination of challenges from a currency devaluation, political instability and a large explosion in the center of Beirut. 

We believe that developing educational experiences which promote post traumatic growth in this context is critical to support the development of an anti-fragile society. Thus we offer this paper as a contribution exploring the factors which contribute to our participant’s continued efforts in their entrepreneurial initiatives. Being social entrepreneurs, they are the future of stability in society, creating employment and addressing fundamental needs connected to SDGs. 














The Protective Properties of Group Laughter 
Humor, Character Strengths and Deliberate Rumination For Social Entrepreneurs in Lebanon in Crisis
Factors Contributing to Post Traumatic Growth for Social Entrepreneurs in Crisis
Background: In 2020 the world was challenged by a global pandemic. In Lebanon, the addition of an economic collapse and a major explosion in the capital city brought acute stressors, triggering migration ideation. In this study, we identify factors that support social entrepreneur’s access to post traumatic growth (PTG) by analyzing resilience and character strengths within an entrepreneurship training program in Beirut. 
Methods:  Over the course of Dec 2020 and April 2021 we gathered 21 hours and a half interviews with Lebanese social entrepreneurs going through an entrepreneurship training program, all of whom were living in Lebanon and experienced the August 2020 Beirut port explosion. Alongside these interviews we gathered a set of qualitative data including pre-post assessments of Character Strengths (VIA), Post Traumatic Growth Inventory (PTG-I), Intrusive and Deliberate Rumination (EERI), Entrepreneurial Intent (EI), Resilience (BRCS) and the Impact of Event - Revised (IES-R). Correlations were identified with factors that support PTG and social entrepreneurial ideation. 
Results: Character Strengths are correlated with PTG and there are validated methods for reliably developing strengths of character. One highly leverable strength is humor, and one way humor can support growth is by preventing helplessness. 
Conclusions: While each person’s life journey is unique, we have identified that social entrepreneurship ideation is promoted by prior traumatic experiences if followed by opportunities and support for growth. Traumatic experiences are inescapable in life, and the opportunity educators and trainers have is to understand how to shift the trauma response curve towards growth. Deliberate Rumination, thinking and reflecting about one’s life circumstances can happen spontaneously and importantly they can be nurtured by incorporating them into group facilitations for training programs and schools. 
Implications:  The results of this study increases an understanding of the complex decision making individuals face in a crisis, and offers insights into the factors which support posttraumatic growth and social entrepreneurship. We hope the results of this paper inspire facilitators to incorporate humor, positive structured conversation and to enliven their program with character development. 
Keywords: Post Traumatic Growth, Social Entrepreneurship, Trauma, Lebanon, Training and Education, Character Strengths
Introduction: 
Trauma conscious pedagogies (Mays 2021) are becoming a widespread topic amongst educators in a post-covid-19 world, and in this paper we explore some factors and methodologies that can support growth during times of collective crisis. In 2020 the Lebanese people experienced the coronavirus pandemic, economic crisis as well as an explosion at the Beirut Port which killed over 200 people and left over 300,000 homeless in its wake. Working as an educator with social entrepreneurs in Lebanon we observed a growing frustration with the idea of resilience, with participants seeing it as a passive way oppressors remain in power while the population deals with the consequences of their mistakes. Rather than bounce back, we  began to explore the factors which promote Post Traumatic Growth (PTG) looking beyond resilience and recovery. We ask how can educators going through times of crisis promote anti-fragility, the ability to use difficulties as opportunities for growth?

People respond differently to traumatic events and people’s Character Strengths can provide a framework to understand those responses as well as which traits may support individuals through times of crisis. Character Strengths are 24 relatively stable positive qualities in humans identified through a cross cultural analysis of what makes life worth living. Certain character strengths like kindness, social intelligence and hope have been demonstrated to protect against the negative effects of stress and trauma (Harzer 2015). It was also demonstrated that an overall growth in the Values In Action Character Strengths Inventory is correlated with the Post-Traumatic Growth Inventory (Peterson et al. 2008). Importantly, there’s a growing body of evidence that there are character strength interventions that support people in developing their strengths (Schutte, N. S., & Malouff, J. M. 2018). Assessing the behaviors that promote PTG and life satisfaction, we find deliberate rumination as an important vector. (Triplett, K. N., Tedeschi, R. G., Cann, A., Calhoun, L. G., & Reeve, C. L. 2011) 

The purpose of this study is to deepen our understanding of the factors that promote Post Traumatic Growth (PTG) to support educators working in environments undergoing crisis. Social enterprise support efforts are often funded and established in areas of need and therefore often the participants of these programs are likely to experience difficulties. add our evidence reinforcing the idea that nurturing character strengths as a whole, and hope, judgment, teamwork and humor in particular may increase the likelihood of growth after traumatic events. Previous studies demonstrate that Deliberate Rumination is a contributing factor for PTG and we have been able to identify judgment and teamwork as correlated Character Strengths. Lastly we recommend programs operating in areas and times of crisis to explore interventions to nurture the buffering Character Strengths of hope and humor while cultivating a group dynamic that can promote judgment and teamwork.

Methodology
We’ve used a qualitative analysis method for the exploration of our research, in an attempt to identify potentially unforeseen variables. The author of this paper has been able to utilize their position as the head of Research And Development at Bloom, an organization which operates social enterprise education programs. Prior to the Beirut Port Explosion in August 2020, the participants and applicants for the Bloom social entrepreneurship accelerator program had taken the Values In Action Character Strengths Inventory (VIA-IS). At the conclusion of the four months long accelerator, and following the Beirut Explosion, all applicants to the program requested to complete a post-test VIA-IS inventory, those in the program and those not selected.

An analysis of the pre/post test data for the VIA-IS demonstrated a buffering effect experienced by individuals who were a part of the Bloom program, which led to in-program individuals maintaining their overall VIA average while individuals outside the program experienced a significant drop. To understand this phenomenon was the genesis of this research, and inspired the qualitative/quantitative research methodology described below.

Qualitative Analysis: 
The qualitative analysis consisted of twenty one 1.5 hour long interviews, which were all conducted remotely and recorded digitally. The interviewees were split with 10 people coming from outside the training program and 11 people who had gone through the training program (marked as “In prog.”). The interview consisted of open-ended questions as well as questions requesting a qualitative response. The interview corpus was then brought into a software supporting bi-directional links through which code clusters were identified.

Results
Overview of Data and Background Knowledge
After a threatening situation, animals and humans respond in a variety of ways. Initially described by Walter Cannon (Cannon, W. B. 1915) as the Fight or Flight response, the theory has since then been adapted by Dr. Stephen Porges into Polyvagal theory (Porges 2009). This model now includes freezing as an alternative response, and attempts to correlate stress responses to neurohormonal responses. In the face of a situation in which no options seem viable, an individual can either choose to fight, flee (flight) or freeze. We will be using these three types of responses as a framing for potential ways our interviewees responded to the Beirut Blast.

In 2011, Martin Seligman (Seligman 2011) made the hypothesis that PERMA (Positive Emotion, Engagement, Relationships, Meaning, and Accomplishment) comprises well-being, and argues that the model is helpful for measurement as well as for application (Seligman 2018). 
Before we get into the analysis of the data, please review the prior description of the data and data gathering phase. If you would like to explore the data yourself, you can find a public dataset available to review here: http://bit.ly/cs-data-21 

The Character Strengths data was gathered as part of the application process for a social entrepreneurship program before the August 4th, 2020 explosion. After the explosion, to understand deeper changes in entrepreneurial ideation we conducted a second VIA-IS as well as a new questionnaire using the new measures described above. To start the exploration as to the factors which support social entrepreneurs we keep in mind the question: who grows as a social entrepreneur in times of adversity and who reprioritizes the notion of their career trajectory to focus more on self preservation. In 2008 Christopher Peterson (Peterson et al. 2008) demonstrated a positive correlation between the VIA-IS Character Strengths Inventory and the Post-Traumatic Growth Inventory (PTGI; Tedeschi & Calhoun, 1996). The PTGI measures growth on the dimensions of Appreciation, New Possibilities, Relating to Others, Spiritual Enhancement and Personal Strength; interestingly, all of these dimensions are relevant for social entrepreneurial ideation. Comparing PTGI with the Character Strengths assessment we identify that Humor, Teamwork, Spirituality, Prudence and Judgement have a significant correlation for PTGI across the five sub-dimensions, see figures below.

Data validity questions. 
We initially hypothesized that there would be a correlation between CS prepost (Character Strengths Difference in average scores assessed before/after the blast) and Post Traumatic Growth. While there seems to be a slight correlation between CS prepost and PTGI - Appreciation (.33 p-val .14) we cannot at this time with our limited data make any strong statements about Character Strength changes before/after an explosion and PTGI. One factor could be that the time frame for the post test was taken over a 3 month period (December - March 2020) and it might be interesting to study a progression of changes rather than comparing pre and post. Growth takes time and measuring over an extended period confuses the data. Also, assessing people earlier, and therefore closer to the period of the traumatic event may not have left time to metabolize the experience while people who filled in the assessment later have had more opportunities. Another bias that may be influencing the data is potentially the types of people who submit forms early compared to those who wait may also capture proactive people early in the recovery process and procrastinators later in their process. Rather than adding another factor to control for procrastination, I propose future assessments to include deadlines for inclusion into the dataset, or to include time of receipt as an influencing factor. 
 
And now, we begin to explore motivation and wellbeing for entrepreneurs following the Fight, Flight and Freeze framework. 
Fight
After the Beirut Explosion, many of the interviewees were feeling anger. Although anger may be seen as a negative state, we found that many of the participants used their anger towards a factor we called Revolutionary Ideation, clicking this link will take you to see sections of the interview tagged with this concept. 

“Angry at the government, of course. Angry that the city I love was destroyed. The nice things about our city were destroyed in a second because of the irresponsibility of the people governing. Of course I went to the protest that happened immediately after” - Interview 006

Some people went to the streets to protest, while others viewed their entrepreneurial activity as their “action” in response: 

“With the revolution came many different revolutions... one of the revolutions we're making is in education. And I say that I'm an activist  and not on the ground - it's our revolution in education. I don't think the revolution is only about going down and doing it violently. It's about rethinking, unlearning, recreating. Putting aside everything traditional / forced upon us / trying to make a difference. not just to make money. Money is not the aim, it's the reward. It's not the reward I'm aiming for. The impact is the aim I want. There's lots, revolutions in media, education, revolution in feminism/sexuality. This awareness is coming out and has been a social revolution not only (taboo). Not just a gov /political revolution, it's everything. This is my revolution.”
-Interview 019

As you can see from the chart above, the majority of participants with revolutionary ideation came from people who were not intending to leave Lebanon, even after the blast. While revolutionary thinking and political engagement is not the primary focus of this paper, it is worth being included here since many of the inspiration for social entrepreneurs comes from areas the public sector is lacking in, and can be seen as a form of direct action. Most of the social entrepreneurs interviewed for this paper were operating businesses solving problems in the domain of education. 

Another important reason to consider the idea of “Fighting” and using the feeling of Anger is that it is a fact bound to happen, especially when paired with major traumatic events. So rather than avoiding the feeling, we can sublimate anger to increase the critical factor of engagement to prevent freezing, complacency, and inaction. While the language of fighting is not necessarily positive, it does imply a high degree of activation and purpose, something important to maintain in the face of conflict and insurmountable odds. 

The measure we’ve selected for “Fight” is resilience, labeled BRCS  (Sinclair and Walston 2004), it measures the following questions on a 5 point scale:
	1	I look for creative ways to alter difficult situations. 
	2	Regardless of what happens to me, I believe I can control my reaction to it. 
	3	I believe I can grow in positive ways by dealing with difficult situations. 
	4	I actively look for ways to replace the losses I encounter in life.

Acting as an antidote to the potential freezing reflex, resilience inspires action and engagement. While focusing on character strengths development has been shown to support wellbeing factors described by PERMA (Goodman & Kauffman 2017), there appears to be a subset that stands out in our set of interviews. The components of this subset are the following : Hope, Humor, Self-Regulation, Social-Intelligence and Teamwork. We can see that these are especially correlated with resilience, and may be interesting to explore as in future studies. 
What might not support direct engagement? The following table presents negative correlations between Revolutionary Ideation that we can find identified in the data, there are no strong positive correlations to present. 


The relationships that stand out to me are the relationship between Prudence, having a child and Revolutionary Ideation. Prudent parents are less likely to be engaged in protests and other types of activism. Another strong correlation is with Spirituality. Diving into how one mother responded to the explosion we can see both features at play:

“No, nothing changed. God's will will still happen as it should. Nothing has changed. I worked as a mother to prevent the impact from impacting my children much so they don't stay home alone. I didn't have much capacity to go to the site to volunteer. Fadi my brother was there and saw the fire that became the blast and was more present. I personally focused on making sure my children would cross this situation without harm. Fadi worked on support.”
-013 Interview Spirituality rank 7/24 & Has_Child True

While the strength of Spirituality contributes positively to Post Traumatic Growth through the “Spiritual Enhancement” facet, there is a concern that over-focusing on the strength of spirituality could lead to spiritual bypassing, which is a coping strategy where people use spiritual ideas to avoid facing unresolved emotional issues and development tasks. Spiritual bypassing was coined by John Welwood and developed in (Cashwell, C. S., Glosoff, H. L., & Hammond, C. 2010).  
Interviewee number 18 expressed the balance between trusting in the “Will of God” and developing and engaging in acts of control like this:
“We do have control over that, if it's going to happen it's going to happen. If maybe we knew about it, maybe it's going to happen anyway. We're destined to have this. There's a saying in the (The Islamic Spiritual Tradition), aqqqalal (Arabic for use your brain/do something rational) watawakal (Arabic for rely on God) - before submitting (to the will of God) do what you have to do. DO what we should do and at the end of the day what's going to happen is going to happen.”
-018 Interview 

Figure 6 in the figures section below displays an interesting chart exposing some relationships between meditation, spirituality, revolutionary / social ideation. Spirituality is correlated with not having a therapist perhaps indicating that people with a stronger spiritual practice don’t identify with the need to find a therapist. This is interesting because it seems that having a therapist correlates with deliberate rumination and meditation. Reviewing age seems to indicate that the younger generations are more open to therapy and meditation alongside their religious and spiritual beliefs. 

One takeaway from the above analysis is that creating mixed communities of practice where various spiritual, religious, therapeutic ideas are shared openly might create an opportunity for alternative perspectives to be displayed and their results seen, either amplifying or dampening the ideas that the group selects as valuable. This might be an important task for course designers and facilitators to navigate carefully. 013 expressed a value in action by nurturing their child, while 019 demonstrated Bravery and a rallying cry to contribute socially in a time of revolutionary change. In relation to the theme of this section, both of them are putting up a good fight and are engaged in a values informed course of action.

Flight
Traumatic events are destabilizing to the individual since it can shatter mental models, self image and worldviews, and while possibility of rebuilding these offer a potential avenue for change and positive growth for the individual given the right context, environment and support (Roepke, A. M., & Seligman, M. E. P. 2014) how people choose to respond is highly variable. In the previous section we described people who engage (flight), this time, let’s discuss migration (flight).
Flight is an inevitable response that many people have when something tragic happens. Prior to the blast, Lebanon had a migration challenge where the World Bank data indicates that about 40 percent of male and 30 percent of female university graduates leave Lebanon upon graduation (WorldBank 2014). While it is still too early to tell what the migration impact of the explosion will be, the total population of Lebanon has dropped .44% last year and (Ibrahim 2020) reports that the number of people leaving Lebanon increased by about 30% in the first month after the blast. Understanding the decision making process of social entrepreneurs is critical since they are an important part of the population working on creating stability and creating positive reasons for people to stay, either through their services, as employees or customers. 

This snippet of dialog from an interview demonstrates in real time holding multiple perspectives and ends with a contradiction, to desire to want to stay. 

“For instance if I had kids. If I was in Beirut/ lost a close family member I may have thought I would leave. Fortunately for me I don't’, it’s related to how much they can take. My brother is leaving for France in September, I can't leave everyone/my family. We have the family business, my father is relatively old. And I want to stay here willingly.”
-004 Interview

The research strategy was initially going to divide the population into “those who stay and build” and “those who leave and protect themselves and their families” - during the coding process we found that the decision is emotional some people want to leave and contribute, and some want to stay and contribute, and many others have competing commitments that are unclear. Sometimes the interviewee demonstrates deep self knowledge and desires to leave for strategic reasons, to continue to be able to offer their work life as a service to their community they need to stay safe, sane and alive: 

“I won't lie, sometimes I feel like leaving too. Why do I think about it? To keep this engine/enthusiasm/giving to people I have to feel secure. Not that I will die at any instant. So much is online so I can do so much of my work online. I can be effective even if I’m not physically in the country. I think of my safety, my family… and my earnings. Now I’m fine. After a while will I still be fine? I’m investing from my income, will I still be able to invest in my team? That’s the one thing I’m thinking about. I’m investing in the base, raising this “child” so that one day the company will come and pay me back and take care of me when I’m older. Thank goodness God has given me a salary. I see tangible results. We’re going to print the book and sell it and make money from it. I can see it all. It's not like we’re playing and not doing anything.
-002 Interview

This powerful snippet from the interview shows the strategic process 002 has taken to rationalize her potential departure from Lebanon. Some questions arise as to how much the combination of the massive spread of the coronavirus and the subsequent lockdown supports people in their migration ideation. It could be that as people have spent much of 2020 indoors people now, like 002, have taken their social entrepreneurship programs online and have less of a physical investment in their physical environments.

Other interviewees have a clearer commitment to leaving and do not seem conflicted in any way:
“I live with my mom/brother. And we are all affected by the situation of course. Because before that - the port - we already had the economic situation and we were feeling safe since a long time nothing happened security wise. we heard it could happen again. We don't feel safe anymore.
I don't have foreign nationality, so I decided not to take a French one. It's complicated to find a job, it's a safe thing to do to have a possibility if one has to go outside Lebanon. I would be interested in leaving if I had an opportunity. Someone said for Canada. Someone said it's very far and they don't take Lebanese for my age. For security reasons I could go to France for example. It's a sure avenue, I need a challenge in my life. I don't like routine.”
-Interview 017

“Participants who maintain calm and develop adaptive self-regulating practices  Actually my thinking is everyone is thinking about leaving. Something inside me that doesn't want to leave despite everything. I don't know why I'm still calm. I see the craziness all around us. The best thing you can do is focus with what you have, and how you can help others with what you have. If you focus on all the bad things around us you can't work. What I decided is to help and doing what I can do and keeping my mental health and family health and that's how to survive everything. Of course we felt very bad and it was very stressful for us and all these feelings. I just wanted to stay calm.”
-014 Interview

Albert Bandura’s Social Cognition Theory (Bandura 1989) proposes that a portion of knowledge acquisition comes from social evaluation, from our data we see that people modulate their migration ideation based on many factors, one of which is how and who they speak to about it. Traumatic events disrupt the standard narrative model needing new stories to support meaning, suggests Neimeyer in (Neimeyer, R. A. (2004), how are those narratives reconstructed? In a paper developing a model of Post Traumatic Growth for cancer patients (Morris, B. A., & Shakespeare-Finch, J. 2011) identified Deliberate Rumination as a strong influencing factor for PTG. Further research demonstrated the relationship between PTG and life satisfaction through the factor of meaning:

In the paper (Triplett et al. - 2012), they demonstrated that the disruption of core beliefs (CBIs) triggers both intrusive and deliberate rumination and that the destabilizing aspects of a traumatic event either supports a more meaningful life of satisfaction through deliberately contemplating the experience, or can negatively affect meaning and life satisfaction through intrusive rumination. 

Deliberate Rumination is the process of choosing the questions and thoughts one has around a traumatic event, for instance “what is the lesson I am learning through this” in contrast with Intrusive Rumination and Brooding which may take the tone of “why is this always happening to me”. We can see both examples in our interview data set. Observe as 018 reflects on discussions had during a group dialog with other social entrepreneurs in the entrepreneurial training program:
“...First I was thinking if we stay in this country, I can do anything in this country. Nothing limiting me, why would I leave this country.... Why ... maybe I should have a backup country if something unexpected happens. Just having this backup country in mind can help me (with my project). … Then(the start of the program) (projectName) (personName) starting asking which country do you want to go to? And I started thinking, first that ... I have friends, good nature, why leave? Then after the blast I have a different perspective of the country and started thinking of where I can go when/if something unexpected happens.”
--018 Interview
Other examples of social cognition supporting someone positively through social media and describing the importance of having a community of positive social support to help create a sense of control and meaning as he adjusts his worldview through the development of spiritual and meditative practices: 
“A lot lot lot lot. After the blast I was majorly helped - writing affirmations. It helped me so much. I was in complete loss, not knowing what's happening, what the point of anything is. Self existence questions that you ask yourself. One of the major affirmations, I am control of my reality even in times of uncertainty.
There's a beautiful instagram, called affirmation addict. Girl in California, I don't have the application. I have a journal. I have a routine. Every two weeks. I cleanse my home with spiritual music. I started yoga. More meditation. I did a retreat for 5 days [...]
I always have curiosity to learn more about these. They came at the right time. I have friends who are more spiritual bess (but) i'm doing it alone. At my own pace. I have a collective of friends around me that I'm inspired by.”
-020 Interview

Including moments of Deliberate Rumination in a social setting where trust is first established can potentially support PTG. Including a focus on Strengths which support individuals' sense of life satisfaction and overall wellbeing is hypothesized to set a state of mind conducive to positive Deliberate Rumination. 
The set of character strengths associated with our Deliberate Rumination dimension is Judgement, Social Intelligence and Teamwork. These traits do intuitively make sense as critical factors for deliberate rumination and working together as a community to make difficult collective decisions about traveling, building and relationships. We hope that by bringing a greater awareness to these strengths of character people and programs will benefit from clearer thinking and more open discussion on what to do after difficulties arise. 
Freeze… or Laugh
The third  response individuals have in the face of an overwhelmingly negative situation is to freeze. In our interviews, we identify initial stages after the blast where many people felt stuck through expressing feelings of exasperation and frustration at the situation. Indicating they sense a loss of control. These aspects connect to Post Traumatic Growth (PTG) through negating the opposite, post traumatic stress. Some of the symptoms of PTS are freezing, feeling numbness, an inability to act or care, holding one’s breath, a sense of dread… 

While it’s important not to overstate the case of PTS, in fact, most people respond quite resiliently as proposed by (Bonanno, G. A. 2004), also in order for people to experience the positive effects of PTG even the challenges and stressors of ordinary life can be enough of a trigger to stimulate benefits (Ewert, A., & Tessneer, S. 2019). Before exploring people’s stress let’s explore the positive correlations between PTGI and Character Strengths:

The majority of the connection comes through the facet of PTGI-Appreciation. 


 “...It's useless, they are not serving us by doing this. (Sharing news about the situation) They are producing anger that can't turn into anything. The people are already angry from the economic issue. They don't have proof. One can sit and do theories for hours.”
017 Interview 

“Khalas(exasperated form of “enough” in Arabic). I can't control anything… I need to control my feelings thoughts rage. 
-020 Interview

After a month, yeah. In the first month I was consuming a lot of news about it and then I decided to stop. I was just depressing myself and I couldn't do anything about it and I disconnected completely and living my life as if nothing was going on. [[Code: Response-Self Protection]] I wasn't in Beirut, It wasn't as traumatic I was in Sawfar
006 Interview 

“I didn't force myself to deal, when I wanted to cry. I was crying, when I didn't feel willing to do anything I didn't do anything.”
010 Interview

Rather than freezing in response, some of the interviewees exhibited avoidant behaviors, which parallel freezing:

“After the blast I didn't go to Beirut until just now. It was too heartbreaking, I didn't want to see it. We were impacted from the protests and the views. I was in a state of denial I didn't want to believe that this has happened. I only went yesterday because I //HAD// to get a vaccine. In some buildings you see the effects of the blast, in other buildings it's been cleaned up.”
010 Interview

Contrast the preceding statements with following statements which demonstrate interviewees engaging in highly motivated activities following the explosion:

“When the blast happened, most businesses closed and people were cleaning up... When I was in gbeili - company, not antwork. I was looking at the employees and was thinking, don't you want to be in beirut helping other people? You could just go there and do something, this paperwork could be done another day.”
019 Interview 

“I still have nightmares, I have PTSD. Do you really want to know what it's like? I had some calls with people from projectName. And suddenly the glass office I was in all collapsed and the couch I was sitting on was full of glass. Allah itlatuf (God intervened with mercy) it was a matter of minutes. I was caught up on my way down to the floor below with my manager having a silly discussion when the blast happened. And the whole lower floor was full of blood, everyone had to be taken to the hospital. We were so scared to move. Because there were two we expected a third. We all thought we were being blasted. Because of this we created a (product in response), it was a determination for us that (curseword) it we're staying. We're doing this for the country despite all the (curse) we're living through. It was created after the blast as a demonstration that we want to manufacture here, we want to create jobs, we want to build something for the kids that are deprived of toys, their childhood even.” https://roamresearch.com/#/app/EntrepreneurialResearch/page/ISYEjUAMD

Traumatic experiences are inescapable in life, and the opportunity educators and trainers have is to understand how to shift the trauma response curve towards growth. Deliberate Rumination, thinking and reflecting about one’s life circumstances can happen spontaneously and importantly they can be nurtured by incorporating them into group facilitations for training programs and schools. 
Implications:  The results of this study increases an understanding of the complex decision making individuals face in a crisis, and offers insights into the factors which support posttraumatic growth and social entrepreneurship. We hope the results of this paper inspire facilitators to incorporate humor, positive structured conversation and to enliven their program with character development.

Introduction: 
Trauma conscious pedagogies (Mays 2021) are becoming a widespread topic amongst educators in a post-covid-19 world, and in this paper we explore some factors and methodologies that can support growth during times of collective crisis. In 2020 the Lebanese people experienced the coronavirus pandemic, economic crisis as well as an explosion at the Beirut Port which killed over 200 people and left over 300,000 homeless in its wake. Working as an educator with social entrepreneurs in Lebanon we observed a growing frustration with the idea of resilience, with participants seeing it as a passive way oppressors remain in power while the population deals with the consequences of their mistakes. Rather than bounce back, we  began to explore the factors which promote Post Traumatic Growth (PTG) looking beyond resilience and recovery. We ask how can educators going through times of crisis promote anti-fragility, the ability to use difficulties as opportunities for growth?

People respond differently to traumatic events and people’s Character Strengths can provide a framework to understand those responses as well as which traits may support individuals through times of crisis. Character Strengths are 24 relatively stable positive qualities in humans identified through a cross cultural analysis of what makes life worth living. Certain character strengths like kindness, social intelligence and hope have been demonstrated to protect against the negative effects of stress and trauma (Harzer 2015). It was also demonstrated that an overall growth in the Values In Action Character Strengths Inventory is correlated with the Post-Traumatic Growth Inventory (Peterson et al. 2008). Importantly, there’s a growing body of evidence that there are character strength interventions that support people in developing their strengths (Schutte, N. S., & Malouff, J. M. 2018). Assessing the behaviors that promote PTG and life satisfaction, we find deliberate rumination as an important vector. (Triplett, K. N., Tedeschi, R. G., Cann, A., Calhoun, L. G., & Reeve, C. L. 2011) 

The purpose of this study is to deepen our understanding of the factors that promote Post Traumatic Growth (PTG) to support educators working in environments undergoing crisis. Social enterprise support efforts are often funded and established in areas of need and therefore often the participants of these programs are likely to experience difficulties. add our evidence reinforcing the idea that nurturing character strengths as a whole, and hope, judgment, teamwork and humor in particular may increase the likelihood of growth after traumatic events. Previous studies demonstrate that Deliberate Rumination is a contributing factor for PTG and we have been able to identify judgment and teamwork as correlated Character Strengths. Lastly we recommend programs operating in areas and times of crisis to explore interventions to nurture the buffering Character Strengths of hope and humor while cultivating a group dynamic that can promote judgment and teamwork.

Overview of Data and Background Knowledge
After a threatening situation, animals and humans respond in a variety of ways. Initially described by Walter Cannon (Cannon, W. B. 1915) as the Fight or Flight response, the theory has since then been adapted by Dr. Stephen Porges into Polyvagal theory (Porges 2009). This model now includes freezing as an alternative response, and attempts to correlate stress responses to neurohormonal responses. In the face of a situation in which no options seem viable, an individual can either choose to fight, flee (flight) or freeze. We will be using these three types of responses as a framing for potential ways our interviewees responded to the Beirut Blast.

In 2011, Martin Seligman (Seligman 2011) made the hypothesis that PERMA (Positive Emotion, Engagement, Relationships, Meaning, and Accomplishment) comprises well-being, and argues that the model is helpful for measurement as well as for application (Seligman 2018). 
Before we get into the analysis of the data, please review the prior description of the data and data gathering phase. If you would like to explore the data yourself, you can find a public dataset available to review here: http://bit.ly/cs-data-21 

The Character Strengths data was gathered as part of the application process for a social entrepreneurship program before the August 4th, 2020 explosion. After the explosion, to understand deeper changes in entrepreneurial ideation we conducted a second VIA-IS as well as a new questionnaire using the new measures described above. To start the exploration as to the factors which support social entrepreneurs we keep in mind the question: who grows as a social entrepreneur in times of adversity and who reprioritizes the notion of their career trajectory to focus more on self preservation. In 2008 Christopher Peterson (Peterson et al. 2008) demonstrated a positive correlation between the VIA-IS Character Strengths Inventory and the Post-Traumatic Growth Inventory (PTGI; Tedeschi & Calhoun, 1996). The PTGI measures growth on the dimensions of Appreciation, New Possibilities, Relating to Others, Spiritual Enhancement and Personal Strength; interestingly, all of these dimensions are relevant for social entrepreneurial ideation. Comparing PTGI with the Character Strengths assessment we identify that Humor, Teamwork, Spirituality, Prudence and Judgement have a significant correlation for PTGI across the five sub-dimensions, see figures below.

Data validity questions. 
We initially hypothesized that there would be a correlation between CS prepost (Character Strengths Difference in average scores assessed before/after the blast) and Post Traumatic Growth. While there seems to be a slight correlation between CS prepost and PTGI - Appreciation (.33 p-val .14) we cannot at this time with our limited data make any strong statements about Character Strength changes before/after an explosion and PTGI. One factor could be that the time frame for the post test was taken over a 3 month period (December - March 2020) and it might be interesting to study a progression of changes rather than comparing pre and post. Growth takes time and measuring over an extended period confuses the data. Also, assessing people earlier, and therefore closer to the period of the traumatic event may not have left time to metabolize the experience while people who filled in the assessment later have had more opportunities. Another bias that may be influencing the data is potentially the types of people who submit forms early compared to those who wait may also capture proactive people early in the recovery process and procrastinators later in their process. Rather than adding another factor to control for procrastination, I propose future assessments to include deadlines for inclusion into the dataset, or to include time of receipt as an influencing factor.

So what is a theory behind humor and this buffering effect? Humor has been linked to adaptive coping and keeping a “light attitude” in the face of adversity (Ruch and Hofmann 2017). Humor is also an active response to take when other options are unavailable: people “break” the silence with laughter, for example. This may be preventing the processes which lead to Learned Helplessness. Learned helplessness is one way to view the opposite of post traumatic growth for people living in highly chaotic and destabilized situations. Initially Learned Helplessness theory implied that dogs experiencing inescapable shocks learned helplessness and persisted in helpless behavior even when the situation became escapable later. 

Recent research has shed light on the neurological underpinnings of learned helplessness which has application in uncertain times (Maier, S. F., & Seligman, M. E. P. 2016). Previously Learned Helplessness, as the name suggests, theorized that higher level mammals learn helpless behaviors when they are given inescapable negative experiences. Passivity in the face of a changed situation, a situation where it behooves the animal to take action, is the hallmark of learned helplessness. And while that behavior doesn’t change, our understanding of how it comes to be has. Mammals, when confronted with prolonged adverse situations, develop an unlearned response of passivity. It is possible to overcome this bias towards passivity by learning and exerting control. What behaviors are available to act on?

One additional mechanism could have explanatory strength is the Broaden and Build theory (Fredrickson B. L. 2004) which espouses that positive emotions support people in expansive activities, and taking action builds new capacity for further positive emotion, expansive activities and capacities. The question underpinning the research on a pool of 21 social entrepreneurs (with half in an
entrepreneurial program and half outside of it) centers on the question: how do we nurture and
motivate social entrepreneurs in a values oriented program? We attempt to answer this question
by understanding the impact of the traumatic event (IES-R) for “fight”, their deliberate and
intrusive rumination amongst social entrepreneurs in Lebanon for “flight” and their potential
resulting growth (PTGI) for “freeze”. We will describe the reasoning for the mapping shortly.
Previous research by Christopher Peterson has demonstrated that improvements in Character
Strengths are correlated with improvements in the Post Traumatic Growth Index, for people that

Methodology
We’ve used a qualitative analysis method for the exploration of our research, in an attempt to
identify potentially unseen variables. These unseen variables support the exploration of those
factors that contribute to, or detract from commitment, to social entrepreneurship. The author of
this paper has been able to utilize their position as the head of Research And Development at
Bloom, an organization which operates social enterprise acceleration and education programs.
Prior to the Beirut Port Explosion in August 2020, the participants and applicants for the Bloom
social entrepreneurship accelerator program had already taken the Values In Action Character
Strengths Inventory (VIA-IS). At the conclusion of the four months long accelerator, and
following the Beirut Explosion, the applicants who were not selected as well as the participants
who were a part of the program requested to complete a post-test VIA-IS inventory. An analysis
of the pre/post test data for the VIA-IS demonstrated a buffering effect experienced by
individuals who were a part of the Bloom program, which led to in-program individuals
maintaining their overall VIA average while individuals outside the program experienced a
significant drop. To understand this phenomenon was the genesis of this research, and inspired
the qualitative/quantitative research methodology described below.

The reasoning behind having a qualitative and quantitative approach was to be able to identify

Challenges:
Following an inductive tagging methodology, in which novel categories were derived from
interviews, led to a challenge in which not all participants were asked relevant questions. For
example, it became clear that prior experience with violence - such as living through the 2006
war - may have potential relevance on the responses people had to the current time of tumult.
This observation led some of the data in our table to be segmented to three categories: True,
False and Unsure.
Another challenge came up in regards to perceived social expectations of the interviewer during
the interview, sometimes referred to as Demand Characteristics, a theory expounded on by Orne,
Martin T. (2009). Some participants qualified their responses with statements like: “I only put a
four because I didn’t experience it directly myself.” This happened on repeated occasions with
individuals who seemed to be embarrassed by the fact that they were feeling high levels of
negative impact from the effects of the Beirut Port Explosion, without actually witnessing it
directly, being injured or knowing people who have been injured or killed.
The process of going wide with the qualitative interview and going deep with the quantitative
measures has exposed variables and areas of study that would not have been obvious at the start
of the research process. To add a final note, the VIA-IS assessment was done as an online
questionnaire outside the interview structure allowing us to compare pre-post tests, and with the
entire set of VIA Inventories conducted with 260+ entrepreneurs.

Data Analysis and Insights:
Overview of Data and Background Knowledge
After a threatening situation, animals and humans respond in a variety of ways. Initially
described by Walter Cannon (Cannon, W. B. 1915) as the Fight or Flight response, the theory
has since then been adapted by Dr. Stephen Porges into Polyvagal theory (Porges 2009). This
model now includes freezing as an alternative response, and attempts to correlate stress responses
to neurohormonal responses. In the face of a situation in which no options seem viable, an
individual can either choose to fight, flee (flight) or freeze. We will be using these three types of
responses as a framing for potential ways our interviewees responded to the Beirut Blast.
In 2011, Martin Seligman (Seligman 2011) made the hypothesis that PERMA (Positive Emotion,
Engagement, Relationships, Meaning, and Accomplishment) comprises well-being, and argues
that the model is helpful for measurement as well as for application (Seligman 2018).
Before we get into the analysis of the data, please review the prior description of the data and
data gathering phase. If you would like to explore the data yourself, you can find a public dataset
available to review here: http://bit.ly/cs-data-21
The Character Strengths data was gathered as part of the application process for a social
entrepreneurship program before the August 4th, 2020 explosion. After the explosion, to
understand deeper changes in entrepreneurial ideation we conducted a second VIA-IS as well as
a new questionnaire using the new measures described above. To start the exploration as to the
factors which support social entrepreneurs we keep in mind the question: who grows as a social
entrepreneur in times of adversity and who reprioritizes the notion of their career trajectory to
focus more on self preservation. In 2008 Christopher Peterson (Peterson et al. 2008)
demonstrated a positive correlation between the VIA-IS Character Strengths Inventory and the
Post-Traumatic Growth Inventory (PTGI; Tedeschi & Calhoun, 1996). The PTGI measures
growth on the dimensions of Appreciation, New Possibilities, Relating to Others, Spiritual
12

Enhancement and Personal Strength; interestingly, all of these dimensions are relevant for social
entrepreneurial ideation. Comparing PTGI with the Character Strengths assessment we identify
that Humor, Teamwork, Spirituality, Prudence and Judgement have a significant correlation for
PTGI across the five sub-dimensions, see figures below.
Data validity questions.
We initially hypothesized that there would be a correlation between CS prepost (Character
Strengths Difference in average scores assessed before/after the blast) and Post Traumatic
Growth. While there seems to be a slight correlation between CS prepost and PTGI -
Appreciation (.33 p-val .14) we cannot at this time with our limited data make any strong
statements about Character Strength changes before/after an explosion and PTGI. One factor
could be that the time frame for the post test was taken over a 3 month period (December -
March 2020) and it might be interesting to study a progression of changes rather than comparing
pre and post. Growth takes time and measuring over an extended period confuses the data. Also,
assessing people earlier, and therefore closer to the period of the traumatic event may not have
left time to metabolize the experience while people who filled in the assessment later have had
more opportunities. Another bias that may be influencing the data is potentially the types of
people who submit forms early compared to those who wait may also capture proactive people
early in the recovery process and procrastinators later in their process. Rather than adding
another factor to control for procrastination, I propose future assessments to include deadlines for
inclusion into the dataset, or to include time of receipt as an influencing factor.

Traumatic events are destabilizing to the individual since it can shatter mental models, self image
and worldviews, and while possibility of rebuilding these offer a potential avenue for change and
positive growth for the individual given the right context, environment and support (Roepke, A.
M., & Seligman, M. E. P. 2014) how people choose to respond is highly variable. In the previous
section we described people who engage (flight), this time, let’s discuss migration (flight).
Flight is an inevitable response that many people have when something tragic happens. Prior to

that the number of people leaving Lebanon increased by about 30% in the first month after the
blast. Understanding the decision making process of social entrepreneurs is critical since they are
an important part of the population working on creating stability and creating positive reasons for
people to stay, either through their services, as employees or customers.

So what is a theory behind humor and this buffering effect? Humor has been linked to adaptive
coping and keeping a “light attitude” in the face of adversity (Ruch and Hofmann 2017). Humor
is also an active response to take when other options are unavailable: people “break” the silence

implied that dogs experiencing inescapable shocks learned helplessness and persisted in helpless
behavior even when the situation became escapable later.
Recent research has shed light on the neurological underpinnings of learned helplessness which
has application in uncertain times (Maier, S. F., & Seligman, M. E. P. 2016). Previously Learned
Helplessness, as the name suggests, theorized that higher level mammals learn helpless behaviors
when they are given inescapable negative experiences. Passivity in the face of a changed
situation, a situation where it behooves the animal to take action, is the hallmark of learned
helplessness. And while that behavior doesn’t change, our understanding of how it comes to be
has. Mammals, when confronted with prolonged adverse situations, develop an unlearned
response of passivity. It is possible to overcome this bias towards passivity by learning and
exerting control. What behaviors are available to act on?
One additional mechanism could have explanatory strength is the Broaden and Build theory
(Fredrickson B. L. 2004) which espouses that positive emotions support people in expansive
activities, and taking action builds new capacity for further positive emotion, expansive activities

2020 brought many challenges to the already challenging field of Social

In our programs, and for impact monitoring, we utilize the Values in Action Character

worthwhile, and supports us in finding ways to help bring out people’s strengths in
pursuit of their social entrepreneurial aims.
Our research found that wellbeing and life satisfaction correlate with self-efficacy
and productivity factors. The more teams feel resourced to face the challenges of life
and work, even in chaotic times, the better the outcomes for the teams and their
social initiatives.
Bloom's research team is currently conducting qualitative and quantitative research
to contextualize the changes seen within the Character Strengths of our participants.
Reviewing the data in the context of the challenges that people in Lebanon have
faced over the last year, the question was raised: How our programs may have had an
impact on the people who were part of our programs? We are interviewing
participants that went through the full 6 month (originally planned as 4 month)
Accelerator Program (May-October 2020) and those who only went through the 2

respond to and grow through challenging situations and how those responses differ
within a program and outside a program. We’re doing this to identify better the
factors which lead to Post-Traumatic Growth (PTG is defined below) to then include
these factors more deeply into our programming.
This document describes a recently identified buffering effect for participants
within the ACSI program on the measure of Character Strengths overall and a more
substantial buffering effect on factors relating to Wellbeing and Life Satisfaction.
Post-Traumatic Stress vs Post-Traumatic Growth
Trauma and the accompanying stressors that persist do impact many people who go
through an acute traumatic event, like the blast that went off in Beirut last year, or

sustained challenges such as those emerging from the pandemic, economic
collapse, and others. Individuals may have trouble concentrating, flashbacks,
sensitivity to similar situations, and other negative experiences that develop after a
traumatic event are called Post Traumatic Stress Disorder(PTSD). The research shows
that after a traumatic event, there are three main responses:
● 
A small percentage of people who experience it develop PTSD,
● 
The majority of people show resilience and return to the pre-event state,
● 
Another minority demonstrates something called Post Traumatic Growth.
(Jeon 2015)
In Post-Traumatic Growth, following a period after a traumatic event that is spent
grappling with the challenges - there is a period of growth whereby people develop
new strengths, see new possibilities, develop spiritually, develop closer relationships,
and a deeper appreciation for life.
These days, more programs are becoming trauma-informed and are adapting
accordingly, but there is little inclusion of this in entrepreneurship programs, and
little research focusing on how entrepreneurship programs can better support
communities during and after traumatic events, and better support post-traumatic
growth. In an age of disruption and “new normals” understanding what supports
PTG is critical.

Practical Program Applications of our Hypotheses
A key objective of our programmatic approach in Bloom is to combine these critical
aspects of character and universal skills development into our entrepreneurial
support programs, since success of social impact and traditional enterprises is
intimately connected to the capacities of the team, especially founding and early
team, of an enterprise. The more effective programs can be on both enterprise and
personal development factors, the more impactful the programs can be both in the
short-term and long-term. This is even more critical in emerging ecosystems and
marginalized/vulnerable communities where character and skill development
opportunities are less available, and where exposure to acute and sustained
traumatic experiences are more common.
Further Exploration
Further exploration will be how to deepen the factors supporting these traits and
engender post-traumatic growth for an age of instability and chaos. Some of the
factors that are correlated with increased potential for Post Traumatic Growth are
Social Support as well as Deliberate Rumination (Morris, B. A., & Shakespeare-Finch, J.
2011).

The programmatic implications of the factor analysis above along with the
assessment of strengths open lines of inquiry about the potential benefit of making
conscious the discussion of strengths. Deliberate Rumination is the process of
choosing the questions and thoughts one has around a traumatic event, for instance
“what is the lesson I am learning through this” in contrast with Intrusive Rumination
and Brooding which may take the tone of “why is this always happening to me”.
Including moments of Deliberate Rumination in a social setting where trust is first
established can potentially support PTG. Including a focus on Strengths which
support individuals' sense of life satisfaction and overall wellbeing is hypothesized to
set a state of mind conducive to positive Deliberate Rumination. A traumatic event is
destabilizing to the individual since it can shatter mental models, self image and
worldviews, the possibility of rebuilding these offer a potential avenue for change
and positive growth for the individual given the right context, environment and
support (Roepke, A. M., & Seligman, M. E. P. 2014). Over the course of one’s life the
majority (> 60% across many countries) of people will experience an event which they
report as traumatic (Scott, K. M., Koenen 2013).

1/ Context
Bring to the table and describe the object/thing/phenomenon you decide to study.
Entrepreneurship education is a methodology gaining traction in sustainable
development as a persistent way to increase employment, reduce inequality, and

M2 Lesc 20-21 - U.E. Research Project - A. Legavre & N. de Chanaud
increase stability. In these countries, the entrepreneurial landscape is non-ideal due
to the additional challenges within the political and economic landscape. Potential
violence and social unrest entrepreneurs must deal with plus the usual stress and
challenges of operating an enterprise. The additional stressors of an entrepreneur
working in a conflict-prone area on top of the challenges of capitalising and
operating in conditions of uncertainty shine a light on the need to understand
emotion, affect, character strengths and resilience alongside more traditional
economic and entrepreneurial measures.
The insights gained from the edge cases of entrepreneurship education will bear
fruit for educators, policymakers, and multinational NGOs who seek a sustainable
development path. Challenges and stressors confront anyone wanting to create
change and identifying cross-culturally relevant interventions to nurture resilience
and support entrepreneurial orientation, action, and success will be beneficial.
2/ Presentation of references
To clarify the challenges and opportunities presented to governments, universities
and other entrepreneurial ecosystem facilitators this review goes over a subset of the
literature discussing:
● 
Entrepreneurial Intent (Zhao, Seibert, & Hills, 2005),
● 
Entrepreneurial Orientation and Intent
● 
Entrepreneurial Cognition and Action
And viewing them in relation to:
● 
Self-efficacy (Benight & Bandura, 2004)
● 
Resilience / Post Traumatic Growth
● 
Emotion / Affect - as mood and passions (Baron 2008)
● 
And hope - defined as a cognitive capability in as opposed to an emotion
(Arend 2020).
Within this literature review, the following relevant questions were salient in regards
to identifying the factors relating to entrepreneurial intent and action in conflicted
areas:
1. 
What mediates entrepreneurial self-efficacy?
2. 
How do conflict and trauma promote or demote the factors leading to
entrepreneurial motivation and action?
3. 
What interventions enhance the promoting factors and inhibit the demoting
factors leading to entrepreneurial motivation and action?
Concepts

Within question 1, we identified the concepts of positive affect (Bernoster et al. -
2020), and metacognition as factors that support entrepreneurial self-efficacy.
Within question 2, we identified the concepts of Post-Traumatic
Growth(Shakespeare-Finch 2011), Brooding VS Rumination (Garcia 2014), and Hope
(as cognitive capability VS emotion).
Conceptual Map Example: Positive Affect mediates between Self Efficacy and Innovative
Behaviors.
Within question 3 we identified the concepts of Signature Strengths training within
the Values in Action Character Strengths model (Schutte and Malouff - 2019),
Reappraisals and positive reinterpretation (Scheier, Weintraub, & Carver, 1986),
Deliberate Rumination, Benefit Finding (Ai et al. 2005), and Social Support.
The surveyed papers demonstrate a lack of specificity between positive affect, life
satisfaction, and happiness (Schutte 2019).
Results
It is clear that affect matters. The literature reviewed demonstrates that positive
affect mediates the relationship between self-efficacy and the innovative behavior of
entrepreneurs. (Mielniczuk 2020) which aligns with (Bandura, 1997)’s explanation of
how self-efficacy enhances wellbeing and outcomes.
(Uy et al. 2017) demonstrated that higher Affect Spin (the dynamics of changing
mood/feelings) impedes progress on entrepreneurial milestones. The impact
remains, regardless of the type of affect Spin - either entirely within the positive
range or ranging from positive to negative. Affect stability is related to wellbeing and
wellbeing pertaining to goal orientation and goal orientation to supporting venture
progress.

M2 Lesc 20-21 - U.E. Research Project - A. Legavre & N. de Chanaud
What inhibits progress for entrepreneurs in conflict and challenged areas? Across
studies, we find that intrusive rumination and brooding stemming from a traumatic
event mediate the relationship between subjective and post-traumatic symptoms
(García 2015). The monitoring that comes from a metacognitive perspective can be
related to intrusive rumination. In (Learning 2015) we see that metacognition is the
mediating factor between Social Support and Wellbeing.
The previous results demonstrate the correlates of affect and internal narrative to
entrepreneurial behaviors and intention. Metacognition also plays a vital role as a
mediator of wellbeing while highlighting a question of the role metacognitive
processes have in types of rumination.
Continuing the explanation of trauma, rumination and wellbeing as factors upstream
to entrepreneurial outcomes (Triplett, Tedeschi, Cann, Calhoun and Reeve 2012)
conducted a path analysis to identify how traumatic experiences lead to increased
life satisfaction. They identified the process of Deliberate Rumination (sometimes
mediated/triggered by Intrusive Rumination) to be a core factor.
Meaning and story making is a subtext across much of the literature read about
trauma and entrepreneurship. It is a concept which underlies rumination in the
previously discussed studies. As described in (Janoff-Bulman 1989) - a traumatic
event may lead to posttraumatic stress due to a break in our assumptive worlds, the

M2 Lesc 20-21 - U.E. Research Project - A. Legavre & N. de Chanaud
schema we come to expect is no longer relevant. Meaning connects things, and
traumatic events and disruption disconnect them (Park 2010). It is becoming clear
that one way Deliberate Rumination supports Post-Traumatic Growth and through
that can support entrepreneurship in the developing world is through the
accompanying resilience of PTG and the reappraisal and the telling of a new story.
The relationship between deliberate and intrusive rumination, affect, and action is
becoming a clear exploration area. (Baumeister and Wilson, 1996) identified four
needs for meaning: Need for purpose, need for value/justification, the need for
efficacy, and finally the need for self-worth. (Bullough et al., 2014) have demonstrated
a relationship between entrepreneurial self-efficacy and resilience with
Entrepreneurial Intent. The integration of self-efficacy between the needs for
meaning and a component supporting entrepreneurial intent demonstrates the
complex web of effects that inspire or dim the light on entrepreneurship
motivations.
Lastly, Posttraumatic Growth is identified through the development of specific
character strengths. (Peterson 2008) demonstrated the development of particular
Character Strengths for individuals who have gone through a traumatic experience
at some time in their lives. Peterson identified this growth an arbitrarily long time
after the traumatic event without conducting an intervention; this is intriguing since
it reinforces the theory (Bonanno 2004) proposes - that resilience and Post-traumatic
growth are the general response most people undergo posttraumatic experience as
a part of the natural healing process. While Bonanno suggests that some
interventions (journaling to help with reappraisal) may encourage Post-Traumatic
Growth, the research demonstrates many paths to PTG and many people find it
independently. An uplifting perspective.
4/ Limits of the existing studies
Measurement challenges:
The majority of the papers in this study used self-reported measures and
recommended alternative approaches to assessing factors. (Bernoster et al. - 2020)

M2 Lesc 20-21 - U.E. Research Project - A. Legavre & N. de Chanaud
Issues with non-longitudinal studies: How to define success? Measuring Self
Efficacy and Resilience, as correlates to Entrepreneurial Intent (Bullough 2013), found
convincing evidence. However, without measuring entrepreneurial behavior and
entrepreneurship impact (jobs created, families sustained, the positive impact of
entrepreneurial activities), the demonstration of the correlation between resilience
and self-efficacy with entrepreneurial intentions opens the doors to longitudinal
studies exploring outcomes of those intentions.
Along with desiring to validate their study across in diverse cultures outside Spain
and Portugal, (Mortan 2014) identified that their research is limited by the shortage
of empirical evidence on the relationship amongst Entrepreneurial Self-efficacy and
how it is related to Emotional Intelligence and Entrepreneurial Intention. (Mortan
2014)
5/ Research question
Some questions emerge after reviewing the literature: How does engaging in an
entrepreneurial task impact emotions - how are they reciprocal? Are there
positive/negative spirals, and how what starts them, stops them, encourages them?
What are the interrelationships between emotion and cognition and entrepreneurial
phenomena (Shepherd, 2015)? What is the relationship between metacognition,
rumination and entrepreneurial self-efficacy?
All important questions. Due to prior acquisition of Character Strengths Data
(pre/post) for people within and without an entrepreneurship program (ACSI)
identifying changes and after the Beirut Blast of 2020, there is an opportunity to ask
a new question:
What factors supported the development of Character Strengths and PTG for
entrepreneurs in Lebanon after the Beirut Blast?
The relevant factors can be determined through qualitative interview referencing
some of the concepts referred to in this literature review (rumination, PTG,

metacognition, social support, etc.). A theoretical model will be developed to identify
the strongest correlations that buffered the individuals within the ACSI program
from a 1 point drop in their Character Strengths their peers outside the program
experienced. This knowledge will support other entrepreneurial educators in
similarly challenging environments to improve their programs and support
entrepreneurs working to create a better world. This knowledge will help conflict
zone entrepreneurs grow from their challenges, like a phoenix.

To derive unique and valuable insights from the interviews, it's essential to analyze the recurring themes, unique experiences, and the interplay of various factors highlighted by the participants. Here's a step-by-step approach to uncover additional insights and analogies from the interviews:

Step 1: Identify Recurring Themes
Post-Traumatic Growth (PTG): Many participants discuss growth following adversity, indicating that certain factors contribute to resilience and recovery.
Character Strengths and Values: Themes like courage, perseverance, and hope frequently appear.
Humor and Coping Mechanisms: Several interviewees mention using humor and creativity as ways to cope with trauma.
Social Support: The importance of family, friends, and community support is emphasized.
Entrepreneurial Spirit: Despite adversity, participants show a strong inclination toward entrepreneurship and innovation.
Step 2: Extract Unique Analogies and Insights
Analogy of Resilience as a Muscle:

Resilience can be compared to a muscle that strengthens through use. Just as muscles grow stronger with repeated stress and recovery, individuals develop resilience by facing and overcoming adversities. This analogy can illustrate how the participants' repeated exposure to challenges has fortified their resilience over time.
Entrepreneurial Ecosystem as a Garden:

The entrepreneurial ecosystem in a post-crisis environment can be likened to a garden. Just as a garden requires nurturing, proper conditions, and protection from external threats, the entrepreneurial ecosystem needs support, resources, and stability to thrive. This analogy can highlight the participants' need for a conducive environment to foster innovation and growth.
Humor as a Pressure Valve:

Humor can be described as a pressure valve that releases the emotional tension built up from traumatic experiences. This analogy helps explain how participants use humor to manage stress and maintain their mental health, providing a unique perspective on coping mechanisms.
Social Support as a Safety Net:

Social support functions as a safety net, catching individuals when they fall and helping them bounce back. This analogy underscores the crucial role of family, friends, and community in the participants' recovery and resilience.
Post-Traumatic Growth as a Phoenix:

Post-traumatic growth can be likened to a phoenix rising from the ashes. Despite the destruction and loss, individuals emerge stronger, wiser, and more capable. This powerful imagery can encapsulate the transformative journey of the participants.
Step 3: Highlight Unique Insights
Role of Entrepreneurial Training in Resilience:

Entrepreneurial training programs not only equip individuals with business skills but also foster resilience and adaptive thinking. This dual benefit suggests that such programs could be an effective tool in presilience training, preparing individuals to handle future adversities better.
Interplay of Humor and Social Support:

The combination of humor and social support creates a powerful coping mechanism. Humor helps to lighten the emotional burden, while social support provides practical and emotional assistance. Together, they form a comprehensive support system for individuals facing trauma.
Cultural Context of Resilience:

The cultural context significantly influences resilience and coping mechanisms. In the case of Lebanese participants, the cultural emphasis on community, familial support, and entrepreneurial spirit plays a pivotal role in their resilience. This insight can contribute to the broader understanding of how cultural factors impact post-traumatic growth.
Impact of Systemic Factors on Individual Resilience:

Systemic issues like political instability and economic collapse profoundly affect individual resilience. Participants' narratives highlight how external factors can either hinder or enhance their ability to recover and grow. This insight emphasizes the need for systemic changes to support individual resilience.
Adaptive Innovation in Crisis:

The crisis has spurred adaptive innovation among participants. Faced with limited resources and numerous challenges, they have developed creative solutions to sustain their businesses and support their communities. This demonstrates the potential for crises to drive innovation and resourcefulness.
Step 4: Propose Unique Research Contributions
Study on Presilience Training Through Entrepreneurial Programs:

Research how entrepreneurial training programs can serve as presilience training, enhancing individuals' resilience before a crisis occurs.
Humor and Social Support in Coping with Trauma:

Investigate the synergistic effects of humor and social support on post-traumatic growth and resilience.
Cultural Influences on Resilience and Post-Traumatic Growth:

Explore how cultural values and practices shape resilience and coping mechanisms in different populations.
Systemic Factors and Individual Resilience:

Examine the relationship between systemic issues (e.g., political instability, economic conditions) and individual resilience and post-traumatic growth.
Adaptive Innovation in Crisis Environments:

Analyze how crises stimulate adaptive innovation and resourcefulness among affected populations.
By synthesizing these insights and analogies, you can develop a deeper understanding of the factors contributing to post-traumatic growth and resilience, potentially making significant contributions to academic literature in this field.

This study explores how entrepreneurs in Lebanon navigated the compounded crises of political instability, economic turmoil, and the devastating 2020 Beirut Port explosion. Through in-depth interviews with 21 entrepreneurs, we uncover the strategies and mindsets that enabled them to adapt, innovate, and thrive in the face of adversity. Our findings highlight the crucial role of resourcefulness, flexibility, and creative problem-solving in building entrepreneurial resilience. We identify specific approaches, such as leveraging social networks, pivoting business models, and embracing uncertainty, that entrepreneurs employed to navigate the challenges and seize opportunities for innovation. Drawing on these insights, we propose a framework for resilient innovation in conflict zones and discuss the implications for entrepreneurship education, policy, and practice. Subtitle: Lessons from the Beirut Port Explosion for Creating Trauma-Informed Entrepreneurial Ecosystems

We propose a model for integrating psychological safety and collective healing practices into entrepreneurial organizations and discuss the implications for building resilient and sustainable entrepreneurial communities. This research bridges the gap between organizational behavior and entrepreneurship literature, highlighting the critical role of organizational support in promoting individual and collective resilience in the face of adversity.
